You lay down and try to sleep, but your dreams are filled with the image you Goggled, her living her life, jogging and even getting on a plane and ending up at John's doorstep. You awake in a cold sweat to find yourself.

You look over to see a businessman sitting beside you, with gray hair on the sides of his largely bald head, framing his gentle face and well meaning eyes.

"Ah… a bit of both," You reply, uneasy and trying to hide the precarious situation you are in now. You are largely successful, engaging in small talk and largely passing off as a woman, you think. Suddenly your phone begins vibrating.

"Hello?" you answer, your female voice still not registering as your own.

"Hey babe! I'm here at the airport, gate 18, and I Can’t wait to see you!" an unfamiliar voice says

There's a place in your memory that is blank. Between when you logged off last night till when you woke up on this plane, someone, something changed you and took control for a while, sending you on this crash course.

151111111.title: You land

choices: Sit in the food court, get breakfast, and regroup
Check your reflection in the restroom
1511111112.content:
This is all too much to take. You try to control your breathing so Ms. Nosy next to you won't keep asking questions. The plane is on the ground now and the "Seatbelts On" light has flickered off. The click of passengers unbuckling ripples through the cockpit until a long line of passengers has formed towards the front. You watch people pulling their luggage from the compartments a long time before you realize this is it: you're going to get off and meet this PTSD-suffering war veteran in a city you've never been to as a girl you never met and never wanted to be. Curiosity killed the cat but for you it had more... interesting consequences, and you're not sure they're better.

"Time to get off," Ms. Nosy chirps as she gets up. You follow suit, awkwardly, nearly tripping on the high heels you had no idea were on your feet until now. You grab the seat and Ms. Nosy flashes you an obnoxious smile. "Watch your step, sweetie." Watch yours, you want to mutter, but refrain.

You check for baggage of your own but finding nothing aside from your purse. Jesse (that's the name you picked, you remember) must have counted on ol' John to provide everything. That includes clothes, you realize with a start. That's when you know: you have to get out of here. This is a meeting between two people who don't just want tea and biscuits and you're already deeper than anyone has a right to be. He's out in the terminal, but if you can blend with the crowd...

You try to keep your head low - a difficult thing, since you're a taller girl than most guys in front of you - as you reach the exit and walk the hallway to the terminal. It's a slow, painful walk, made harder in heels and the green dress hugging your body, showing ample cleavage and toned, healthy skin. At least you're surrounded by a good crowd of people. He won't see you right away, if everything works out.

Before you know it (and want it) you're out in the open, surrounded by the hustle-bustle of passengers disembarking, family yelling to them, and announcements over the intercom about delays and arrivals. You have no idea what Mr. John looks like. Did he send you a picture? You can't remember. At any rate it's a moot question. You look for the shortest escape route out of the terminal, a carpeted spot leading to the restrooms and food court, and make a beeline through it. You wait for somebody to scream your name but nothing comes. You're lucky so far... You're going... going... Gone! The terminal trails behind you as you're out in a bigger crowd, away from immediate sight.
1511111112.title: Strike out on your own

15111111122.content:
You're relieved to know you're safe for now. The fear fades and you wonder once again what you look like from an outside perspective. The women's bathroom is the first one you come upon - a stroke of luck, since you'd walk into the men's without thinking - and you step in hesitantly. Is anybody going to notice? There are a lot of women adjusting makeup and sitting in the toilet stalls (No urinals, you notice, but that's expected). They continue their business without giving you a second thought. You really are a woman, you think. That was obvious from the start, but being in a women's bathroom drives the point home. You wait for someone to step away from a mirror and you take their pace.

Wow! The picture of "Jesse Hartford" comes rushing back, now in real-time, and you realize how the picture failed to capture her beauty. Even her hard face, with thin lips, sunken eyes, and sharp cheekbones, gives her a dark, sultry appeal like the femme fatale in a pulp novel. The leaf-green dress shouldn't work with her tan, near-bronze skin but the contrast is subtle enough to draw attention and not overdo it. Seeing her biceps and thighs, the firepower packed in each, fills your brain with vigor. You're healthier than ever, muscular, powerful. You can run for miles without breaking a sweat. You pull at Jesse's ponytail, the same one in the picture, and rub your cheek like you're adjusting make-up, then step away and leave. There's no point in looking for too long. There's a chance you'll never break away.

Outside the restroom, you rummage inside Jesse's purse. There's the cell phone John called you on, a wallet with Jesse's driver's license (Age 25, like you told John, 6'1'', a resident of Boston), a card informing people you're a certified personal trainer, a cosmetic mirror, cosmetics, loose change, and nothing else of interest. You meander towards the airport exit with the phone in hand, flipping through the contacts. Your next goal: find someone who can help you.
15111111122.title: Seeing Jesse Hartford

151111111221.content:
You type in your number from memory, your brilliant green eyes blinking rhythmically in response to your reflection in the cell phone screen. You wait patiently, your breaths doubling the ringing of the call being collected. Suddenly it picks up, a female voice answers.
"Hi"
"Hi, I'd like to speak to Matt please."
"Sorry ma'am, the number you were trying to reach does not exist. There's no Matt at that number nor anyone else."
You end the conversation and pause for a moment. Not only did your prank change you, it changed the world around you. Or, what if you've always been Jesse Hartford and in a delusional trail you've made up the whole other life, your life.
151111111221.title: Call Yourself

choices: Awaken as Jesse Hartford a few minutes later.
Awaken as Matt Pullman one week later.
1511111112211.content:
"I know I'm not crazy" you whisper as you set the phone back into your new purse. There's no way you could have the memory of being a man and absolutely no memory of being a grown woman. Something happened and you are determined to find out who was behind this and change back to your normal self.

But that's when you feel it; a small, slightly crumpled and folded piece of paper wedged into a corner of the purse that brushed across your slender fingers. Curious, and a bit baffled that you didn't see it before, you pull the paper out and begin to unfold it, your new green eyes widening in shock at what you see. There, on the obviously well worn page is the smudged yet still graceful print of what you assume has to be this body's handwritten script.

YOU ARE JESSE HARTFORD. THIS IS YOUR MEMORY PAPER.

YOU WENT TO ST. MARY'S PRIVATE SCHOOL IN BOSTON. YOUR PARENTS ARE HELEN AND CHARLES HARTFORD. YOU GRADUATED FROM EMMANUEL COLLEGE. YOUR THERAPIST'S NAME IS DR. JANICE KOWALSKI. YOUR BEST FRIEND IS RACHEL BARKER. YOU OWN HARTFORD BODYWORKS ON FIFTH & GREEN STREET. YOU HAVE HAD OVER THIRTY-TWO PERSONAL CLIENTS AND EMPLOY TWENTY-SEVEN STAFF. YOU HAVE BEEN AWARDED BEST GYM & SPA TWICE AND HAVE BEEN FEATURED IN DAYSPA MAGAZINE.

REMEMBER!!!

MATT IS NOT REAL AND YOU ARE NOT HIM! HE IS A FIGMENT OF YOUR IMAGINATION. YOU HAVE MULTIPLE PERSONALITY DISORDER FROM CHILDHOOD TRAUMA. YOU TAKE MEDICINE TO CONTROL THIS. BLACKOUTS CAN TRIGGER THE SWITCH.

REMEMBER, MATT IS NOT REAL!

YOU ARE JESSE HARTFORD!

You feel an unbearable pressure well up in your chest and your vision goes blurry as warm, salty tears fill your eyes. The paper and your purse fall from your hands as you grow weak and light-headed from the information you just read. Matt never existed. you never existed. this is all just some strange and sick dream that life pulled on you to make you think you were a man.

"I'm Jesse Hartford..." you whisper, and a small, yet defiant voice in the back of your mind screams out "NO! You're Matt Pullman! You have a whole life of being a teenage boy in your head and no memory of being this woman! Someone did this to you!"

But it's too late, amidst the stress of the moment and the overwhelming proof in front of you, you pass out on the airport floor. The last thing you see is the sight of a security guard running towards you before your head hits the tile.
1511111112211.title: Not crazy, but not quite sane.

choices: The ruined future of Jesse Hartford.
151111111221111.content:
You make a mad dash for the exit, terrified of someone finding out that you are sometimes a teenage boy who doesn't really exist. You kept it a secret for so long, and have built such a name for yourself that even on the other side of the country you're terrified of Jesse Hartford being known as someone crazy and unreliable. You'd be ruined! Your entire business would go bankrupt and mom and dad would be quick to disown you! You'd have to become a stripper! Or worse!

In your blind panic you fail to heed the cries of the medics to stop, or the blaring security alarms that begin to cry out as the medics report you as uncooperative and a possible threat to airport security. You have to get outside, disappear into the city, you can only think about getting out of here! Luckily you're as fit as a woman can be, and you race through the airport at a blistering speed, shouting at the top of your lungs for people to move out of your way.

But then your entire body seizes up as something hits you in the side! You fall to the tile floor with a heavy thud and convulse as the electrical energy from a tazer courses through you, and then it's gone, replaced by the heavy hands of several security guards that quickly handcuff you and frisk you for any potential weapons as you lie there in a daze, your hair pooling around your face as you gasp for air and try your best not to start sobbing or to piss yourself.

As the security guards drag you to a nearby transport cart, you feel the eyes of the silent terminal upon you and you can only hang your head in shame. You're ruined. Even if they don't find your memory paper, you're still going to have your face plastered across the news everywhere in the country.

You feel the hot, salty tears pouring out of your eyes as you lower your head into your hands and sob as quietly as you can.

Jesse Hartford, you, are finished.

151111111221112.content:
"What? Oh, yes, thank you." You say pleasantly as the handsome paramedic pulls you to your feet. You don't purposefully give him a nice glance at your cleavage but at the same time, you're not upset that he snuck a look. After all, you're very proud of your body and all the work you put into keeping it fit and attractive.

"Miss, we'd like to take you to our medical station here in the terminal just to make sure you're alright. Just as a precaution before we let you on any planes or out into the main airport, we'd like to take your blood pressure, just a quick check up to make sure your vitals all check out. Do you have anyone waiting for you or are you getting ready to board? We'd like to contact anyone who might be waiting on you and escort them to the medical desk" The paramedic asks as you bend down to pick up your purse and your Memory paper. You quickly fold the paper up and stick it back in your purse, no reason to draw any more attention to yourself given how paranoid most airports have become in recent years.

"Of course sir" You smile up at the medic as you sling your purse back over your shoulder, "I actually have someone waiting for me at Gate 8. His name is John and I think I have a picture somewhere on my phone...I just had to use the bathroom so suddenly, I guess the oxygen difference between the plane and the terminal just got me a little light headed. I'm so sorry for all of this." With that you pull out your expensive smart phone and quickly flip through the familiar pictures until you find the image your potential suitor had sent you. "Here, this is what he looks like" you say as you had the paramedic your phone, but he gently refuses it.

"I'm sorry miss, but we'll have to wait until we get to the medical desk to contact him. Now, right this way..." With that the paramedic guides you towards the small three person cart he and his partner arrived in. You hook your arm in his just to be flirty for the hell of it, but you didn't just spend almost a thousand dollars to fly this far to run off with the wrong man. He motions you towards the back seat and you quickly climb in and take a seat in front of the flashing red and blue warning strobe light. The paramedic leans in and quickly fastens the specialized seat belt for you before seating himself in the front passenger seat. With a nod to his partner sitting at the wheel, you take off down the terminal.

As you watch the crowds pass by in a low speed blur, you take a deep breath to help calm down.

"Another blackout" You think to yourself. "What the hell was I thinking not taking my pills before getting on the plane back in Boston? I'm lucky I didn't try to hijack the plane or cause too much of ruckus. I'd hate to be sitting in airport security..." You shudder as you try not to think about being strip searched. You don't think you could live with the humiliation of being another statistic of 'women who were visually raped at the airport'. Your thoughts turn to John briefly before you realize no one is going to be able to collect your luggage, and you lean forward to speak your concerns to the paramedic.

"Don't worry, ma'am. As soon as we reach the station we'll have someone retrieve your luggage and bring it to you. It's the least we could do" He says in his best 'please don't sue us' voice, but you still appreciate the courtesy. Not many people get this sort of treatment after all. You remember the time you came back from a week in Mexico with your friends, that was SUCH a nightmare getting through Customs and all the rude officials who bossed everyone around like cattle.

The cart slows as you pull up to a rather nondescript looking door with the words "AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY" printed in large blue letters above it, and you are quickly escorted inside to what is the local logistics hub for airport employees in this particular terminal. The paramedic quickly checks you in at the desk, taking your luggage and the information you have about John, and disappears out the door with a brief smile. You are quickly brought into a simple examine room where another medic proceeds to check you for any injuries, take your pulse and get a brief report on what happened out in the terminal. You give him the full story that you told the paramedic, but don't mention your other personality that has plagued you for twelve years. Satisfied, the new medic escorts you to a small waiting room down the hall.

Taking a seat in one of the chairs, you prepare yourself for meeting your potential match.
